questions.question: What UNESCO World Heritage Site in the Middle East is famous for its rock-cut architecture and water conduit system, dating back to the 4th century BCE?
questions.context: Known as the 'Rose City', it was the capital of the Nabataean Kingdom and is one of the most popular archaeological sites in the world.

questions.question: What UNESCO World Heritage Site in Europe is a baroque palace surrounded by expansive gardens, associated with the Age of Enlightenment?
questions.context: This palace was the principal royal residence of France from 1682 under Louis XIV until the French Revolution in 1789.

questions.question: What historical site in Asia is a UNESCO World Heritage Site known for its giant stone temples, constructed in the early 12th century as a Hindu temple complex, but later transformed into a Buddhist temple?
questions.context: This site is the largest religious monument in the world and a symbol of Cambodia, appearing on its national flag.

questions.question: Which UNESCO World Heritage Site in Africa is known for its ancient pyramids and the Great Sphinx, built during the reign of Pharaoh Khufu?
questions.context: Standing some 450 feet (137 meters) high, the Great Pyramid was the tallest structure in the world until the Middle Ages.

questions.question: What UNESCO World Heritage Site in South America is a historical sanctuary believed to be a royal estate, built in the 15th century and rediscovered in 1911 by Hiram Bingham?
questions.context: This iconic citadel is located on a mountain ridge amid the Andes Mountains and is a lasting symbol of the Incan Empire.
